report.report_description: Air pollution is one of the most important environmental threats to urban populations and while all people are exposed, pollutant emissions, levels of exposure, and population vulnerability vary across neighborhoods. Exposures to common air pollutants have been linked to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, cancers, and premature deaths.
report.report_text: Categories based on whether the most recent neighborhood value falls among the best, middle or worse performing third of all NYC neighborhoods. NYC is divided into 42 neighborhoods based on the United Hospital Fund (UHF) approach of aggregating zip code areas to approximate Community Planning Districts.
report.report_footer: More data and information on Outdoor Air and Health can be found on the NYC Tracking Portal (www.nyc.gov/health/tracking) and on EpiQuery (www.nyc.gov/health/epiquery). The tracking program is part of the National Environmental Public Health Tracking Network (www.cdc.gov/EPHTracking).
report.unreliable_text: **Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated health events attributable to PM2.5 exposure over natural background levels in NYC (average annual rate per 100,000 residents).

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Deaths due to all causes among adults aged 30 years and older 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Estimating deaths that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution increases mortality.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Cardiovascular hospitalizations in adults aged 40 years and older.  2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: PM2.5 can cause cardiovascular hospitalizations, which represent part of the health burden of fine particle air pollution.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Asthma emergency department visits among children under 18 years of age 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: PM2.5 can cause asthma ED visits, which represent part of the health burden of fine particle air pollution.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Respiratory hospitalizations in adults aged 20 years and older 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Estimating hospitalizations that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution impacts public health.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Asthma emergency department visits in adults 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: PM2.5 can cause asthma ED visits, which represent part of the health burden of fine particle air pollution.

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated health events attributable to ozone exposure over natural background levels in NYC (average annual rate per 100,000 residents).

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Asthma emergency department visits among children under 18 years of age 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Ozone can cause asthma ED visits, which are part of the health burden of air pollution.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Asthma hospitalizations among children under 18 years of age 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Ozone can cause hospitalizations for asthma, which are part of the health burden of air pollution.
Ozone can cause hospitalizations for asthma, which are part of the health burden of air pollution.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Deaths due to cardiac and respiratory causes among all residents 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Estimating heart and respiratory deaths that can be linked to ozone is a way to understand how air pollution increases mortality.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Asthma emergency department visits among adults 2015-2017
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Ozone can cause asthma ED visits, which are part of the health burden of air pollution.

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated annual boiler emissions per km2 as of January 2015.  Calculated using heating fuel type on NYC boiler permits and estimates of boiler activity.

report_topic_data.indicator_description: Boilers are a common source of PM2.5, which can harm health.
Boilers are a common source of NOx emissions, which can harm health.
Boilers are a common source of SO2, which can worsen lung disease.

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated annual average concentrations calculated from a model that used NYC Community Air Survey measurements.

report_topic_data.indicator_description: Sulfur dioxide comes from burning some kinds of fuel oil. As an air pollutant, it can can worsen lung diseases.
Ozone is a common air pollutant that can harm breathing and worsen asthma and other respiratory conditions.

report_topic_data.indicator_name: Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5)(Mean mcg per cubic meter) Annual Average 2021
report_topic_data.indicator_description: Fine particles are emitted by vehicles, building boilers, and other combustion - and are a major form of air pollution that harms health.
Nitrogen dioxide is a pollutant formed by combusion that damage lung tissue, cause breathing problems, and contribute to smog and acid rain.

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated annual average concentrations of known carcinogens that are part of a class of pollutants also known as hazardous air pollutants.

report_topic_data.indicator_description: Formaldehyde is an air pollutant resulting from car exhaust and the manufacture of industrial products. Formaldehyde is a known carcinogen that can also cause irritation to eyes and lungs and increase risk of asthma and trigger asthma symptoms.
Benzene is an air pollutant resulting from motor vehicle and industrial emissions and tobacco smoke. Benzene is a known carcinogen that can also harm bone marrow and red blood cell function.

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated millions of annual vehicle miles traveled per km2. Vehicle miles traveled is an indicator of emissions from automobile exhaust, brake wear and tire wear.

report_topic_data.indicator_description: Traffic density is a measure of the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.
Traffic density is a measure of the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.
Traffic density is a measure of the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.
